pros: Financial support: Graduate student assistantships often come with a stipend or salary, which can help cover the cost of tuition and living expenses while you are pursuing your degree. Professional development: Assistantships can provide valuable experience and training in your field of study, as well as the opportunity to work with and learn from experienced professionals. Networking opportunities: Assistantships can provide the opportunity to meet and work with other graduate students and faculty members, which can be valuable for building your professional network. Reduced course load: Depending on the terms of your assistantship, you may be able to reduce your course load or take a break from coursework while you are working as an assistant.
cons: Time commitment: Graduate student assistantships often involve a significant time commitment, which can be demanding in addition to your coursework. Limited flexibility: The duties and responsibilities of an assistantship may leave you with less time and flexibility to pursue other opportunities or interests. Limited advancement opportunities: Depending on the nature of your assistantship, you may have limited opportunities for advancement or professional development beyond your current position. Limited compensation: The financial compensation for graduate student assistantships may be limited, especially compared to other employment opportunities.

review_title: Really depends on who you work for!
pros: The assistantship pays for the tuition and covers the cost of living, and after couple semesters of teaching or being TA for the same course, it will become less time-consuming.
cons:
As a TA, you are the easy target for both the students and the main professor of the course. If you be nice to the students, some of them will try to absue it, and the professor will blame you for it. If you be strict, students will complain how boring and "not nice" you are, and again you will face complains from both the students and the professor.
The strategy that I developed was to think that no matter what I do some students will complain and try to blame their failure in the course on me, so instead of being nice or strict, I tried to perform in a way that I can defend it in front of the professor, at the end of the semester, and try to have an email documented for giving any extension or my answers to them.
Also, there are some professors that will drown you with grading everything! Stay away from them!

job_title: Program Coordinator I in Columbia, SC
pros: U of SC is a great place to work, all things considered. In the department where I am working, there is a high emphasis on work/life balance; staff are not expected to be on their emails after 5PM and they are not expected to check in over the weekend at all. Staff are treated very well by the leadership and faculty in my department, and camaraderie is great. Campus accommodations are nice: some buildings are old but they're all quite clean. During the pandemic, there were a lot of accommodations made for staff and I felt supported by the leadership within the university.
cons: As with many public university staff positions, the pay is not great. The cost of living in Columbia is low, but my salary would not cover my living expenses if I did not live with my partner. It is rather challenging to negotiate a wage raise, much less a promotion within the ranks. It seems easier to pivot to another role in a higher pay band than it would be to receive a raise within your own position.

review_title: U of SC (not to be confused with "Southern Cal") is a typical big business
pros: Able to attract lots of students, and to provide them with an education that is typical for most Ph.D. granting institutions. Salaries are basically competitive with these.
cons:
Administration is like management, with the President making over half a million a year; faculty are like skilled labor, and students (most of the time, the parents pay the piper and call the tune) are the customers. 

And the trend is increasingly in the direction of "the customer is always right" vis a vis faculty. On the other hand, while there are a huge number of scholarships for prospective students, the scholarships obtainable by current students are extremely uncommon and quite small.

True professionalism, very palpable four decades ago, is rare now and is increasingly becoming more rare. 

Camaraderie between colleagues, and between faculty and grad students, has greatly diminished during the same time frame. The influx of Chinese faculty and graduate students has also put a damper on social life: most of them do not mix well with others. 

Grade inflation is a perennial problem, and the pandemic has greatly exacerbated it. For large online classes, "open book, open notes" is almost unavoidable.

Deans are often out of touch with faculty, especially if they are humanities people out of touch with people in the sciences. 

It would be very interesting to know how much of what I have written here is typical of universities. Unfortunately most faculty are not as candid or aware of the big picture at their universities as I am.

review_title: It's a big state school in the southeast
pros: If you like living in the climate of the southeast, and you appreciate the charms of a mid-sized southern city, then UofSC in Columbia, SC can be a great place to live and work. As with any professorship, your experience will be defined primarily by your immediate colleagues: your students, your department, your College. If they are a good match for you, then a career at UofSC can be very pleasant and rewarding.
cons: This large state school is not well-supported by the state, and does not have the resources, prestige or name recognition to compete with the upper tier of state universities. There are some great students at UofSC, and some world-class faculty, but there's also a lot of students who are not really ready for college, and a significant fraction of the faculty that would rather be at a better university.

review_title: Learn What You Can & Move On
job_title: Business Office Coordinator in Columbia, SC
pros: When you find a legit supervisor, learn as much as you can for as long as you can and then move on from U of SC. Use it as a stepping stone for the next career move. Could be a good starting point for individuals who recently graduated with Higher Ed Master's degree looking for experience as Coordinators or 1st time Assistant Director positions.

review_title: Too many offices in basements; tenure should be abolished
pros: Good place to work if you are in the right department with a good director. Many nice benefits for employees, such as free courses, useful classes in HR and wellness activities. Also, if you have a master's degree, you can teach, which is fun plus you earn extra income.
cons: For a place that talks a lot about wellness, a vast number of employees work in desk-bound jobs in basements. They work in five floors of basements below the library, the basement of the coliseum and basement of the old law school. No sunshine year after year is bad for your health. The should install solar tubes to bring in natural light. Also, they should get rid of tenure. Everybody thinks alike as it is, and it leads to an atmosphere of entitlement.

review_title: My experience has been good overall but career development is minimum, especially if staff
pros: Good and friendly environment. Coworkers are professional and follow ethics with exceptions. Good benefits and insurance but could be better. Good city to grow family. Good vision overall. Good programs growing. School of medicine is part of the university and a very nice campus. Good work-life balance overall, although very slow at times.
cons: Lack of leadership is a killer, even though president has a good vision. Career development is not organized with clear objectives by managers or chairs. Teaching is second or third behindresearch and other activities, when it should be main purpose. Lack of knowledge about budgets is another killer. Slow pace work environment, facilities and other services can be a hassle. Parking space is very problematic. Space to grow is already a big problem, especially for faculty research labs. Relationship with industry is getting well behind compare to clemson and musc.

review_title: No concern for employee well being
job_title: Library Technical Assistant in West Columbia, SC
pros: Relaxed work environment, good benefits. Not all departments are the same, but the autmosphere speaks for itself.
cons: It's all about money. Employees don't make money, they cost the University. They care about getting more students and faculty publishing papers. The University doesn't care about issues until they are too late. I was working for USC when the on campus shooting happened. There was no planning or consideration for safety. As a survivor of a shooting incident myself, I had severe PTSD. I was told by my department head to move on and get over it. That's the environment.

job_title: Wellness Center Supervisor in Spartanburg, SC
pros: As a supervisor of the new Wellness Center at the Upstate Campus as well as a student, there are some obvious benefits to working for the same university that I attend. When making my work schedule, the University is very willing to work around my class schedule and give me ample time to study as well. The director of the Wellness Center allows student staff to study for their classes when they have extra time during their shift. Finally, the responsibility and experience I've gained while working here will be invaluable in my future career.
cons: First of all, the hourly wage is not especially high, and the number of hours you get to work is usually very low, around six to nine hours per week. The work can also get to be pretty boring when there is nothing happening, although the staff is allowed to use personal laptops and study for classes. In my opinion, the pros outweigh the cons.

review_title: The updated RA position of the University which is still undergoing changes as time progresses.
pros: Very flexible position which is a must for being a full time student of the University. Knowing that the University is flexible for your schedule means that at times you have to be flexible for the University also. Compensation is great combining stipend salary with 50% off your Housing costs as well as 25% off Meal-Plans if you choose to get one.
cons: High turnover of direct supervisors. Worked 3 years and had 3 different bosses. This leads to rapid changing expectations and management styles for the same job. So Although the job stays the same whats expected of you from the position changes. Bottom level position which at times feels exploited by the University Housing (the Department you're working for). Decisions get made that directly affect your position in very short term with no consultation of RM's.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbia, SC
pros: The faculty are highly supportive and encouraging, you get an office (shared), and the program as a whole is very flexible.
cons: There aren't a lot of funded research opportunities, and for some people, it's too much freedom and not enough structure. The pay is also incredibly low. You're "part-time" for your teaching, TA, and RA responsibilities because you also have your own classes. The pay does not change when you take on your own class as the Instructor of Record. The pay also does not change to accommodate inflation, your initial offer letter is what you get. The only way to increase pay is through and RA opportunity (which is really hard to come by, surprisingly for an R1), your own grant (much later in the program), or if you are allowed to take on more than one class as the Instructor of Record (also much later on in the program). You're kind of left to just... figure a lot of it out for yourself.

review_title: Good place to build your programming skills while being a student
pros:
-- lots of scheduling flexibility; most on-campus jobs will allow you to set your schedule 
-- the ability to learn new languages and frameworks in a sandbox, low-pressure environment
cons:
-- high turn-over and this is not just because most  part-timers are students 
-- projects can feel poorly managed

pros: Some of the East Coast undergrad students from up north are exceptionally bright.
cons: If for some unusual reason you are a prospective graduate student reading this, then please take heed: although this problem lies mostly with the SC state government, be warned that grad. programs at USC (and most all SC, state-funded grad. programs) present one of the absolute worst situations for grad. students and student debt. Unless you enter your grad. program already holding a graduate degree (or plenty of grad. credit hours), then your funding for your first year of grad. study will be very, very poor. So if you are a newcomer and really want to go to grad. school, then do it in another state. . . . Of course, this is mostly advice for non-professional grad. degrees like humanities or social sciences. Many professional grad. degrees (law, counseling, business admin.) don't provide any TA/GA funding anyway.

review_title: Working for the university was a meaningful and enlightening experience, although it was a short-term arrangement.
pros: Working at the academic enrichment center and with the students was an incredibly rewarding experience. Having the opportunity to consult with academic advisers as well as with willing students opened up many avenues to succeed. In addition, staff were supportive in providing materials necessary to do well as an academic mentor.
cons: Despite the strict guidelines from governing bodies, the work can sometimes feel too hands-off. It is difficult to work with some of the students when they sometimes lack basic computer literacy. In addition, some of the upper level staff seem to be distracting themselves while on the job.

pros: This is probably the best place on the planet to work when unexpected family difficulties development.  Whether the issue is a sick child or a sick parent, there is no question about whether time is available to you.  Excellent family care.
cons: As a state institution, raises are minimal or non-existent and salary compression is a major issue.  There is also something of a caste system regarding the relative "importance" of faculty compared to staff.

job_title: Student Services Coordinator I in Columbia, SC
pros: I enjoyed working at USC Columbia, especially working with the students. There are tons of benefits available such as full insurance, discounted parking, continuing education and training, discount programs for state employees (you'll be a state employee) and office events.
cons: office drama... if the supply person doesn't like you then don't expect your pens and paper to come in on time. Also, if you follow the proper chain of command for filing complaints your complaint may never have a resolution. Finally, if you're really good at your job expect others to pile more and more work on you without thanks.

pros: The staff was very friendly they gave me time to understand the system and they didn't rush me. Actually they had to keep finding things for me to do. The office work wasn't hard it just entailed organization skills, document creating, printing, labeling, etc. They weren't too crazy when it came to the office. It was more laid back. You more so had to do things that no one else had the time to do that day. They were very friendly when I asked for help or didn't understand what I was suppose to be doing.
cons: Unfortunately I only had a 2 week internship with them. I would love to work there forever. I don't think there were any cons actually.

pros:
As a former Computer Science grad student instructor: 

- One of the better grad schools as far as financials, income over the cost of living ratio is much higher than the average in the U.S. (mainly because living in Cola is so cheap)
- Friendly work environment, super laid-back in terms of what you can wear to work
- Lots of off days
cons:
As a former Computer Science grad student instructor: 

- Health insurance plan offered by the school is very expensive for a grad student instructor income, and that's without dental
- You may have to cut some slack for student-athletes(only attendance though, not grades) but the football team still sucks, so that can be a little annoying

pros: Great learning experience.  Professors are helpful throughout this roller coaster ride of obtaining the degree, and trust it is a ride!!! There is range of interesting research performed at the Columbia campus. I research colon cancer. Most of the research facilities that I have seen on campus are update in the current technologies to perform adequate research. There are several core facilities that are available to assist students with their research.
cons: The amount of work you perform is not  equally compensated with the pay, but that the life of a graduate student. The student health benefits are alright. I mean it isn't the bare minimum, but it isn't anything to rave about either.

review_title: A terrible place to work. But at least you get time off for your misery.
pros: The vacation time. You get three weeks. You'll need it to continue working here and not want to bang your head against the wall. Of course, you don't get paid anything, so you can't really go anywhere. But at least you can stay in beautiful downtown Columbia! (not)
cons: I don't really think there's enough space, but here's a few: the administration is terrible. The professors and administrators you'll work for (for the most part) are total egomaniacs who only care about their research dollars. They, of course, employ administrative assistants with two year college degrees who are bitter about their lot in life and want to control everything you do.

review_title: Work for USC as a graduate student and your tuition is covered.
job_title: Graduate Instructional Assistant in Columbia, SC
pros: Depending on who you work for, it can be a fun and great learning experience.  At the very least, your tuition is covered.  Very gratifying experience to have students appreciate your hard work and effort.  It's also very convenient that you work on campus and attend your classes.
cons: Obviously the pay is going to suck, but let's face it.  It's a part time college gig.

job_title: Student Services Program Coordinator II in Columbia, SC
pros: Great benefits as a state employee. Specifically in the Financial Aid Office, there are some truly wonderful people that work here. The opportunity to contribute to the advancement of a student's academic career is a special one. The campus is beautiful.
cons: Actual monetary compensation is low in comparison to experience required. In particular to the Division of Student Affairs and other non-revenue generating divisions, funding for raises is solely supported by the specific department's budget. As I've been told, the budget is fixed for the Financial Aid Office. Additionally, advancement opportunities are small. A lot of employees have worked here for a long time, and have no intention on leaving

review_title: An amazing and inspiring place to work
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbia, SC
pros: I have been working for USC in CBM Research Center as a graduate research assistant (GRA). The best thing about CBM is its well-equipped and well-facilitated laboratory. I learned a lot while working here. Another best thing is its friendly environment. Multi-disciplinary team helped me to learn from others and also to get better in communicating while discussing my research findings with others.
cons: At the beginning, I didn't have any dedicated mentors whom I can shadow and get trained. Those were my tough days. But later I picked it up and was doing fine.

review_title: Okay pay (often late or incorrect) and overworked
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbia, SC
pros: Classes are paid for as an Engineering Research Assistant. Students are friendly.
cons:
I've been working at U of SC for 2 years, during my employment my pay has been consistently incorrect resulting in major inconveniences which they are reluctant to fix. Most recently my pay has been delayed by 6 weeks because of an error by HR, the university has not offered any assistance to right this issue. 

As a graduate student, you are obligated to work 20 hrs a week, professors will push you to work 40+ hrs while neglecting vacation time.

review_title: Good Work Life Balance/Poor Team Attitudes
pros: Very understanding of time off, very accommodating of requests for time off, a schedule of Monday-Friday. Very accommodating of school schedule. Some staff members are wonderful resources. Good benefits like health insurance and partial college tuition. The offices are new and very nice to work in.
cons: Poor teamwork, bad attitudes by some team members, other staff are not willing to help each other. Some staff do not complete their work in a timely manner and expect other staff to do it for them. Some staff show up late.

job_title: Research Associate Professor in Columbia, SC
pros: Not a stressful environment, with sufficient external funding one would be left to pursue their own research interests without much obstruction.
cons: Administration does not see the university as a research hub but only as a teaching facility. Not only research is not financially stimulated, it seem to be suppressed by limiting the compensations of research faculty to the level of the teaching faculty regardless of the amount grant funds secured by that research faculty. This policy results in mass exodus of researchers as soon as they land a considerable funding as other universities tend to offer much better terms.

review_title: If you can go somewhere else...
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Columbia, SC
pros: You can make good friends through the program, but you have to seek them out since there aren't any type of well-organized functions for graduate students. The library is also a pro--especially if you want to do any kind of historical work since they have a great collection at the Hollings Special Collections Library. I also loved my students.
cons: Almost no structural support/very little guidance in terms of helping graduate students finish on time. And, as a word of warning, always have other plans set up for employment if you are an adjunct because your classes can be taken away at the last minute.

review_title: Great place to work, as a student or professional!
pros: The staff were very friendly and the environment was typically positive. I always felt appreciated on the job, even while working as a student. Managers are very accomodating with work schedules to conform to class schedules.
cons: In my personal office, a call center, time restrictions on breaks could be difficult to handle. 20 minute lunch breaks go by very quickly. The building in which I worked needed serious repair, and the ceiling above my desk was caving-in. The U doesn't seem to put a lot of effort into building repairs on the older buildings.

review_title: All of the faculty and staff are friendly but they can be a bit needy at times.
job_title: Information Resource Coordinator in Columbia, SC
pros:
You get to make your own schedule.
Any holidays usually give you at least half of the day off before them.
There is a plethora of opportunities for lateral movement as well as advancement.
cons:
Pay is a little low due to departmental budget cuts.
A lot of suggestions made to upper-level supervisors go unnoticed or are not taken seriously.

pros: As a graduate student I was able to immediately put theory learned into real world practice. The faculty was extremely helpful before, during and after I was a student there.  Being able to influence and guide undergrads of the hospitality program was an added bonus!
cons: Unfortunately, the town of Columbia has yet to catch up with the innovation of the university.  Maybe one day the food scene will be a showcase for the school that sits right down the street!

review_title: New Students wants to pursue a PhD in Electrical Engineering
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbia, SC
pros:
Multifaceted work opportunity
You can be a big fish in a small pond
Overall Columbia, SC is a nice place with great weather and laid back environment
cons: Very poor compensation. You have to pay your health insurance, sometimes even part of the tuition fees. Mostly Asian people running this Electrical Dept. So you can understand what to expect, with all due respect to Asians(I am a Asian too).  In short, expects more, pays minimum.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Columbia, SC
pros: The University of South Carolina is the best place to be a PhD candidate. They really set you up for pursuing your further academic dreams. They also provide one on one mentor ship to help tailor your experience for you.
cons: The low income but that goes with being a candidate. Otherwise, all the opportunities are there for you. I've been here for 12+ years and wouldn't leave if I didn't have to.

pros: The pay was great as a student trying to make a bit of extra cash.
cons: You get worked to the bone and really work where you sleep. Definitely feel like you're at the bottom of the food chain and don't get respected even if you have to wake up consistently at 3 am to deal with a resident. The experience overall was just not great.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Columbia, SC
pros: Had a great experience as a teaching assistant in the marine science department.  Very helpful lab managers and coordinators.  Given plenty of independence to teach to my strengths, but was always provided assistance when I needed it.
cons: Depending on what lab or class you teach it can be an incredible amount of work to teach when paired with graduate school classes and research.

pros: Holiday schedule, Sick leave, and annual leave were generous, work environment was great. I had very well qualified coworkers who were using USC as a starting point.
cons: Parking was always an issue, even with a Z sticker that was given to employees. Flexibility regarding schedule and exercise classes could have been better for employee wellness.

job_title: Instructor, Business Writing, Speech, and Composition in Columbia, SC
pros: Availability of funds (usually, although this has changed), relaxed environment, weather is typically nice in the spring and fall. Large student body.
cons: Disconnected administration and faculty, priorities skew towards athletics and business school (extreme, to the point that other disciplines suffer unless you bring in major funding). Resources and infrastructure are extremely limiting. Issues with payroll may leave you without a check without any recourse. Little support from co workers or senior faculty. Teaching is incredibly undervalued and neglected to support research of questionable value.

job_title: Lab Manager and Research Associate in Columbia, SC
pros: Great culture, good environment to do research and live, great resources and access to technology. Good interactions with professors and high tech staff when no egos are involved, it could be very productive when vision is clear.
cons: slow pace, it could be very bureaucratic, could take time to make decisions, needs a stronger and sustainable vision, it could support stronger interactions between professor avoiding personal issues and high egos, it could support own staff growth and career development instead of hiring more people and be more loyal with own personnel.

pros: The faculty are excellent. The facilities are clean. The slection process selects other good doctoral students. The university is low key, and the area has a very low cost of living.
cons: One of the cons is that there is low pay for doctoral students compared to other universities. Another con is the long hours of work that is required of a doctoral student.

pros: Flexible hours and good staff. Working as a student recruiter at the Admissions office was fun and you got the opportunity to recruit students to attend USC. The office also occasionally provided dinner.

review_title: Staff members often treated like inferior humans
job_title: Student Support Services Math Specialist in Allendale, SC
pros: State job, good benefits, good retirement plan i
cons: Staff members are not treated equally, determined by the amount of kissing up one is willing to do. Anyone who asks important questions and expects answers doesn't usually get them.  Administration seems to prefer hiding information from staff and students, as well as from the main USC campus. HR directives regarding workplace ADA compliance is largely ignored. Salaries are low compared to real world salaries. Beaurocratic bull is the norm for this very small campus. The inability to identify and remove incompetent staff is obvious as is the lack of effort to identify and promote intelligent, competent staff. Covering up for staff and/or administrators who don't or can't do their jobs is also obvious. An aversion to being open with the main campus about the goings on at this small campus results in lack of adherence to USC policies and guidelines that are required and expected to be followed. Any attempt by the main campus to investigate this campus usually results in more cover-ups by the adminstration. Unlike The Citadel, illegal activities by students, particularly athletes, go unreported, unprosecuted, and swept under the rug while offenders remain in school and on the team they play for. Amazing.

review_title: The egoism is rampant in the department I worked in but I suppose that comes with the territory.

review_title: I have loved working at this university

cons: There are No cons.  This is a great place to work!

review_title: I would not recommend working at USC
pros: The pros are the campus is nice and clean.  I found the campus to be quiet and peaceful walking around outside.
cons: It is a lot discrimination and racism on this campus. Even though USC welcomes minorities and International students to the campus they are not always treated fairly. As an African American woman employed with USC I was removed from my job because of my race. My supervisor who was a younger white woman did not like me because I had a higher education level than her. She started harassing me on my second week on the job with mild sarcasm. This supervisor only trained me one time during the month I was employed on the campus. However, the other staff member trained me well and I learned all the systems in three weeks time period. The supervisor was very intimidated about me because I learned everything so quickly.  She was determined to get rid of me, so this supervisor went to her manager to lie that I was not doing things correctly. One thing she did not realized is that I would double-check with the staff member who trained me to confirm I was doing everything correctly.  The supervisor waited until I worked all day and as I was walking to my car had the hiring office to call me stating that I was removed from my employment.  The manager who I only saw about three times the entire time I was working there told my hiring office I was punctual meaning on time to work everyday, friendly with staff and students, and had great work ethics. So, I found out from a staff member that this supervisor always remove African American employees from working in that office because she does not want African Americans working in the front office. This is clearly discrimination and racism. I expressed my concerns to the hiring office but nothing was done about this situation. I will be taking this up to a meeting with state officials that can do something about the problems American Americans and minorities are dealing with at USC and other places of employment in the State of South Carolina. Once again, no I do not recommend working at USC in this type of working environment.
